card.name: API
card.desc:
**Authentication**
- Request:
POST /bell/authentication

```
    {
      "username": "x",  
      "password": "y"  
    }
```

PUT /bell/authentication

```
    {
      "hashedCredentials": "x:ffds903j4lfsd0f3j0sdfm"
    }
```

- Response:
```
    {
      "accountId": "959028705943",
      "profiles": [ "pirate" ],
      "hashedCredentials": "x:ffds903j4lfsd0f3j0sdfm"
    }
```
200 | on valid authentication
401 | when user could not be found on server-side

---
**Assets**
- Request:
GET /bell/assets?profiles=X&profiles=Y
Returns all assets that are in licensing window and fit with profiles. X and Y are the profile names that are returned to the user on the authentication call.

- Response:
```
    [
      {
        "title": "My dog Chop",
        "providerId": "HBO",
        "refreshRateInSeconds" : 5
        "media": {
          "mediaId": "fH5yKr_c62A",
          "durationInSeconds": 15
        }
      },
      ...
  ]
```
---
**Alert**
- Request:
GET /bell/alerts

- Response:
```
    {
      "alertId": "2d4be346-120c-11e8-b642-0ed5f89f718b",
      "title": "Emergency Alert",
      "message": "Earth's water level is increasing. Make sure you have a decent bathing suit. "
    }
```

** Modify provider refresh rate **
- Request:
PUT /bell/hidden/provider/{:id}/refreshRate

```
    {
      "refreshRateInSeconds" : 5
    }
```
200 | when successfully updated
400 | when not all fields are provided

** Add and modify asset **
PUT /bell/hidden/asset/{:id}

```
    HEADER: "secretKey": "qwerty123"
    {
      "providerId": "1234",
      "title": "My dog Chop",
      "licensingWindow": {
        "start": "2012-03-22T06:00:00Z"
        "end": "2012-07-02T10:00:00Z"
      },
      "profilesIds": [ "1" ],
      "media": {
        "mediaId": "4NIoUOG_hmg",
        "durationInSeconds": 168
      } 
    }
```
201 | when creation is successful
400 | when not all fields are provided
401 | when secretKey is invalid
403 or 404 | if provider does not exist

** Create account **
POST /bell/hidden/account

```
    HEADER: "secretKey": "qwerty123"
    {
      "accountId": "959028705943",
      "profiles": [ "pirate" ],
      "username": "godo",
      "password": "sensei"
    }
```
201 | when creation is successful
400 | when not all fields are provided or profile does not exist
401 | when secretKey is invalid
409 | when username already exists

** Search **
GET /bell/search?query=<query>

- Response
```
    [
      {
        "title": "My dog Chop",
        "providerId": "HBO",
        "refreshRateInSeconds": 5,
        "media": {
          "mediaId": "fH5yKr_c62A",
          "durationInSeconds": 15
        }
      },
      ...
  ]
```

cards.desc:
MANDATORY!
Business points: 3 

Conditions of success:
- It can be a bash script on a UNIX-like OS or a batch script on Windows
- The server should be running on port 8932 because it is the only human number that the aliens know of.
- The project should contain a README file describing what stories have been completed during the competition
cards.name: [BP:3] As an operator, I can run a bash script that starts both the client and the server

cards.desc:
Business value: 8

Conditions of success:
- The user can see duration of the assets
- The user can see the provider associated to the assets

Plus value if:
- The UI is visually aesthetic for extraterrestrial users
- The navigation is smooth and fun to explore
cards.name: [BP:8] As an extraterrestrial user, I can navigate through available assets

cards.desc:
Business value: 1

Description:
Nothing fancy here. Fetch any asset from the server and just play it! 

Conditions of success:
- The app is able to play any video
cards.name: [BP:1] As an extraterrestrial user, I can watch a video

cards.desc:
Business value: 3

Conditions of success:
- When requesting a stream for a given asset, the media corresponding to the asset is played
- If the asset is not in licensing windows, the server should not return it
cards.name: [BP:3] As an extraterrestrial user, I can play an asset that is available

cards.desc:
Business value: ?

Conditions of success:
- An asset should only be playable if a user has a profile that match this asset AND the corresponding provider
- The backend should not return the asset if it does not match the profiles received as query params

Examples:
- Given a user with a profile 'X' trying to play an asset from a content provider 'P'. The asset has a profile 'X' and the content provider 'Y'. The user will NOT be able to play the asset.
- Given a user with 'X' and 'Y' profiles trying to play an asset from a content provider 'P'. The asset has a profile 'X' and the content provider 'Y'. In this case, the user will be able to play the asset.
cards.name: [BP:?] As an extraterrestrial user, I should not be able to stream a video that does not fit my profile

cards.desc:
Business value: 13

Conditions of success:
- The filter modifies the appearence of the video to display the stream in ASCII art
- The user can toggle the filter in the application at any given time
cards.name: [BP:13] As an extraterrestrial user, I can add an ASCII filter to the stream

cards.desc:
Business value: ?

Conditions of success:
- The filter modifies the appearence of the video to display the stream in a vaporwave aesthetic
- The user can toggle the filter in the application at any given time
cards.name: [BP:?] As an extraterrestrial user, I can add a Vaporwave filter to the stream

cards.desc:
Business value: 5

Conditions of success:
- The most dominant color shade is used as the application background
- The background changes multiple times while playing the same video
cards.name: [BP:5] As a extraterrestrial user, my background color changes depending on the dominant color shade in the video

cards.desc:
Business value: 3

The hashedCredentials is created with the following format: "<username>:<hashedPassword>"

Conditions of success:
- A user with valid credentials can access the guide
- A user with invalid credentials will see an error message and won't have access to the guide
cards.name: [BP:3] As a user, I can authenticate

cards.desc:
Business value: ?

Use the hashed credentials returned on the POST authentication request to refresh your account.

Conditions of success:
- The client app sends its hashed credentials every 5 seconds and refresh its profiles.
cards.name: [BP:?] The client must refresh its session in case of profiles changes

cards.desc:
Business value: 21

Conditions of success:
- The video is displayed in a 3D space
cards.name: [BP:21] As a 3D Enthusiast, I can add a filter to make my stream appear in 3D

cards.desc:
Business value: 5

Conditions of success:
- By using the client app on the path '/hidden' and using the secret key 'qwerty123', an operator can create an asset.
- Assets should be created with: duration, programId, profiles, medias and licensing window
- Assets should always be valid
cards.name: [BP:5] As an operator, I can add and modify an asset

cards.desc:
Business value: 5

Conditions of success:
- By using the client app on the path '/hidden' and using the secret key 'qwerty123', an operator can create an account with a username/password, an accountId and profiles
- As soon as the account is created, the user is able to authenticate
- The hashedCredentials is generated by hashing the password in sha256
cards.name: [BP:5] As an operator, I can create accounts for users

cards.desc:
Business value: 3

Rights can be updated on a regular basis. Therefore, the app should refresh the rights of a given stream. This process is called the "rights refresh rate". Some providers are more subject to changes and therefore, should be updated more often.

Conditions of success:
- The client app refreshes and enforces the stream rights every X seconds
- Any rights modification on the server-side is applied within X seconds
- The video should stop if the user has no longer the right to play a stream
cards.name: [BP:3] As a content provider, I want the rights to be refreshed every X seconds (where X is defined by the content provider)

cards.desc:
Business value: 1

Conditions of success:
- An alarm is displayed every 10 seconds while streaming
- The alarm is defined by the server-side (See the API. You can hardcode your own alarm)

Plus value if:
- The alarm message contains a penguin joke and is politically correct
cards.name: [BP:1] As a streaming platform, I am legally obligated to provide alerts in case of emergencies

cards.desc:
Business value: 1

Condition of success:
- By using the client app on the path '/hidden' and using the secret key 'qwerty123', an operator can select a content provider and update its rights refresh rate
cards.name: [BP:1] As an operator, I can change content provider refresh rate

cards.desc:
Business value: 2

User can enter search keywords to search for content. The search will be done on the following fields "provider.name", "assets.title", "asset.profiles" and "provider.profiles"

Conditions of success:
- Search keywords can be partial. Example, searching for 'ip' should return results for assets with profiles 'Uniped'
- Search should not be case sensitive. Example: 'pirate' should return results for assets with profiles 'Pirate'
cards.name: [BP:2] As an extraterrestrial user, I am able to search content

cards.desc:
--DESCRIPTION --
You are an extraterrestrial life form on Earth without any tools to properly integrate yourself. What's better than news shows and TV shows to open a conversation with humans? 

The goal:
Your task is to create a streaming platform (HTTP REST backend and web frontend) to provide easy access to human content for extraterrestrial life form. You have been given a set of stories with business points for each story. The more business points you complete, the better extraterrestrials will be able to integrate on Earth.

Stories: 
Stories aren't very precise sometimes. Use your imagination to solve the different issues. The only constraint here is the API. Stories are prefixed with BP which stands for Business Points. Some stories have "?" as business points. "?" is a special extraterrestrial number that only reveals itself when your project will be reviewed after the competition. Make sure you invest your time wisely. 

API:
An API has already been defined for most of the stories. This API needs to be used to complete the stories. That being said, you can add any new endpoints that might ease your work (video stream filters for example). 

Streaming:
For the purpose of this challenge, you will be given video ID from youtube that you can play with "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=<videoID>". Those ids can be found in the programming file in your Trello board.

What is mandatory:
- Your team should provide a .sh and/or .bat file that will run the client and server side (see story: """[BP:3] As an operator, I can run a bash script that starts both the client and the server"""). Also, the extraterrestrial operators only know one human number and therefore request that the server run on port 8932.
- A README containing the list of all stories completed and any other relevant information.
- The client side needs to run in a Chrome or Firefox browser
- You must not persist the data (e.g. in the PostgreSQL database). Keep the data only in memory.

-- USEFUL DEFINITIONS --
BP: Stands for Business Point
Programming file: A file describing all the providers and the assets they provide.
Provider: An entity providing content to your platform. They like to have visibility within the platform.
Asset: All the information related to a media you can stream (metadata, media, rights, profiles).
Media: The video bytes. In your case, a youtube video.
Stream: A media currently playing.
Profile: A group of people based on a common trait. In our case, it is completely different from discrimination...
Rights: Restriction applied on an asset. Nothing to do with censorship!
Licensing window: Time frame during which a video is playable.
Rights refresh rate: Frequence at which the rights for a stream are re-applied.
Alert: A message displayed in the application in case of emergencies. Hawaiians may not take it seriously but it is not the case for aliens.
Session: The time between when a user authenticates and when he logs out.
